title: 108_s1702
content: The Act titled "Domestic Partner Health Benefits Equity Act" extends the exclusion for amounts received by an employee through accident or health insurance as reimbursement for medical care. The Act "Domestic Partner Health Benefits Equity Act" amends Section 105(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to include eligible beneficiaries as dependents for medical care expenses. It also introduces an applicable percentage of exclusion for certain amounts for taxable years after December 31, 2004, and before January 1, 2011. The exclusion from income under the Domestic Partner Health Benefits Equity Act is determined by an applicable percentage for taxable years after December 31, 2004, and before January 1, 2011. The applicable percentage for taxable years beginning in 2005-2007 is 25%, and for 2008-2010, it is 50%. These amendments apply to taxable years after December 31, 2004. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include coverage for eligible beneficiaries in employer accident or health plans. The exclusion from income for this coverage is determined by an applicable percentage, which is 25% for years 2005-2007 and 50% for years 2008-2010. The exclusion from income for coverage under employer accident or health plans is determined by an applicable percentage, as shown in a table for different years. The applicable percentage for taxable years varies between 25% and 50% for different calendar years. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2004. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow a deduction for insurance costs of self-employed individuals who are employees. The deduction is for insurance that covers medical care for the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents, with dependents defined as eligible beneficiaries. The applicable percentage of deduction varies between 25% and 50% for different calendar years, starting after December 31, 2004. The deduction for insurance costs of self-employed individuals who are employees varies between 25% and 50% for different calendar years, starting after December 31, 2004. The deduction for insurance costs of self-employed individuals who are employees varies between 25% and 50% for different calendar years, starting after December 31, 2004. The amendment applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004. Additionally, there is an extension of sick and accident benefits provided to members of a voluntary employees' beneficiary association and their dependents. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include provisions for the payment of sick and accident benefits to members of an association and their dependents. This includes individuals eligible for benefits under medical or health insurance programs. Additionally, there is a new subsection regarding the applicable percentage of payment for certain sick and accident benefits. The exemption from tax for sick and accident benefits is determined by an applicable percentage for taxable years between 2004 and 2011. The applicable percentage is calculated based on a specific table. For taxable years between 2005 and 2010, the applicable percentage for the exemption from tax on sick and accident benefits is 25% for 2005-2007 and 50% for 2008-2010. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2004. For taxable years between 2005 and 2010, the exclusion of certain amounts from wages under FICA includes eligible beneficiaries as dependents. The applicable percentage for the exclusion from wages is determined based on the employer's plan or system. The exclusion of certain amounts from wages under FICA includes eligible beneficiaries as dependents. The applicable percentage for the exclusion is determined based on the employer's plan or system. The applicable percentage for the exclusion is determined in accordance with a specific table. For taxable years beginning in 2005-2007, the applicable percentage for the exclusion from wages under FICA is 25%, and for 2008-2010, it is 50%. A conforming amendment to the Social Security Act includes eligible beneficiaries as dependents for medical expenses. The exclusion from wages is based on the applicable percentage of the amount that would be excluded. The exclusion from wages under FICA is based on the applicable percentage of the amount that would be excluded, as determined in accordance with a specific table. For taxable years beginning in 2005-2007, the applicable percentage for exclusion from compensation is 25%, and for 2008-2010, it is 50%. In relation to medical or hospitalization expenses, dependents include eligible beneficiaries as defined by the employer's plan. For taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004, and before January 1, 2011, the exclusion from compensation is determined by an applicable percentage, as shown in a table. For taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004, and before January 1, 2011, the exclusion from compensation is determined by an applicable percentage, with specific percentages listed for different calendar years. Additionally, there is a conforming amendment regarding the definition of 'dependents' for medical or hospitalization expenses under the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974. The exclusion from compensation is determined by an applicable percentage, which is determined in accordance with a specific table. The applicable percentage for exclusion from wages under FUTA for specific taxable years is outlined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term 'dependents' includes eligible beneficiaries as defined by the employer's plan. The exclusion from wages under FUTA for specific taxable years is determined by the applicable percentage, as outlined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The applicable percentage is calculated based on a table provided in the code. For taxable years starting in 2005-2007, the applicable percentage is 25%, and for 2008-2010, it is 50%. These changes apply to remuneration paid after December 31, 2004.
